messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 51 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: The Approximate Degree of DNF and CNF Formulasâˆ—

Paper Abstract: Abstract. The approximate degree of a Boolean function f:{0,1}nâ†’{0,1}:ğ‘“â†’superscript01ğ‘›01f\colon\{0,1\}^{n}\to\{0,1\} is the minimum degree of a real polynomial pğ‘p that approximates fğ‘“f pointwise: |fâ€‹(x)âˆ’pâ€‹(x)|â©½1/3ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘ğ‘¥13|f(x)-p(x)|\leqslant 1/3 for all xâˆˆ{0,1}n.ğ‘¥superscript01ğ‘›x\in\{0,1\}^{n}. For every Î´>0,ğ›¿0\delta>0, we construct CNF and DNF formulas of polynomial size with approximate degree Î©â€‹(n1âˆ’Î´),Î©superscriptğ‘›1ğ›¿\Omega(n^{1-\delta}), essentially matching the trivial upper bound of n.ğ‘›n. This improves polynomially on previous lower bounds and fully resolves the approximate degree of constant-depth circuits (ğ– ğ–¢0),superscriptğ– ğ–¢0(\operatorname{\mathsf{AC}}^{0}), a question that has seen extensive research over the past 10 years. Prior to our work, an Î©â€‹(n1âˆ’Î´)Î©superscriptğ‘›1ğ›¿\Omega(n^{1-\delta}) lower bound was known only for ğ– ğ–¢0superscriptğ– ğ–¢0\operatorname{\mathsf{AC}}^{0} circuits of depth that grows with 1/Î´1ğ›¿1/\delta (Bun and Thaler, FOCS 2017). Furthermore, the CNF and DNF formulas that we construct are the simplest possible in that they have constant width. Our result holds even for one-sided approximation: for any Î´>0ğ›¿0\delta>0, we construct a polynomial-size constant-width CNF formula with one-sided approximate degree Î©â€‹(n1âˆ’Î´)Î©superscriptğ‘›1ğ›¿\Omega(n^{1-\delta}). Our work has the following consequences. (i) We essentially settle the communication complexity of ğ– ğ–¢0superscriptğ– ğ–¢0\operatorname{\mathsf{AC}}^{0} circuits in the bounded-error quantum model, kğ‘˜k-party number-on-the-forehead randomized model, and kğ‘˜k-party number-on-the-forehead nondeterministic model: we prove that for every Î´>0ğ›¿0\delta>0, these models require Î©â€‹(n1âˆ’Î´)Î©superscriptğ‘›1ğ›¿\Omega(n^{1-\delta}), Î©â€‹(n/4kâ€‹k2)1âˆ’Î´Î©superscriptğ‘›superscript4ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘˜21ğ›¿\Omega(n/4^{k}k^{2})^{1-\delta}, and Î©â€‹(n/4kâ€‹k2)1âˆ’Î´Î©superscriptğ‘›superscript4ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘˜21ğ›¿\Omega(n/4^{k}k^{2})^{1-\delta}, respectively, bits of communication even for polynomial-size constant-width CNF formulas. (ii) In particular, we show that the multiparty communication class ğ–¼ğ—ˆğ–­ğ–¯ksubscriptğ–¼ğ—ˆğ–­ğ–¯ğ‘˜\mathsf{coNP}_{k} can be separated essentially optimally from ğ–­ğ–¯ksubscriptğ–­ğ–¯ğ‘˜\mathsf{NP}_{k} and ğ–¡ğ–¯ğ–¯ksubscriptğ–¡ğ–¯ğ–¯ğ‘˜\mathsf{BPP}_{k} by a particularly simple function, a polynomial-size constant-width CNF formula. (iii) We give an essentially tight separation, of Oâ€‹(1)ğ‘‚1O(1) versus Î©â€‹(n1âˆ’Î´)Î©superscriptğ‘›1ğ›¿\Omega(n^{1-\delta}), for the one-sided versus two-sided approximate degree of a function; and Oâ€‹(1)ğ‘‚1O(1) versus Î©â€‹(n1âˆ’Î´)Î©superscriptğ‘›1ğ›¿\Omega(n^{1-\delta}) for the one-sided approximate degree of a function fğ‘“f versus its negation Â¬fğ‘“\neg f. Our proof departs significantly from previous approaches and contributes a novel, number-theoretic method for amplifying approximate degree.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 51 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 51"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Quantum lower bounds for the collision and the element distinctness problems",
        "Construction of a thin set with small Fourier coefficients",
        "Trading group theory for randomness",
        "Complexity classes in communication complexity theory",

        "An information statistics approach to data stream and communication complexity",
        "Quantum lower bounds by polynomials",
        "Separating deterministic from nondeterministic NOF multiparty communication complexity",
        "Separating deterministic from randomized multiparty communication complexity",
        "Multiparty communication complexity and threshold circuit size of ğ– ğ–¢0superscriptğ– ğ–¢0\\mathsf{AC}^{0}",

        "Hardness amplification and the approximate degree of constant-depth circuits",
        "A nearly optimal lower bound on the approximate degree of ğ– ğ–¢0superscriptğ– ğ–¢0\\mathsf{AC}^{0}",
        "The large-error approximate degree of ğ– ğ–¢0superscriptğ– ğ–¢0\\operatorname{\\mathsf{AC}}^{0}",
        "Multi-party protocols",
        "Multiparty communication complexity of disjointness",
        "A measure of asymptotic efficiency for tests of a hypothesis based on the sum of observations",
        "Improved separations between nondeterministic and randomized multiparty communication",
        "A separation of ğ–­ğ–¯ğ–­ğ–¯\\mathsf{NP} and ğ–¼ğ—ˆğ–­ğ–¯ğ–¼ğ—ˆğ–­ğ–¯\\mathsf{coNP} in multiparty communication complexity",
        "Probability inequalities for sums of bounded random variables",
        "The probabilistic communication complexity of set intersection",
        "A note on the sign degree of formulas",
        "Lower bounds on quantum multiparty communication complexity",
        "Disjointness is hard in the multiparty number-on-the-forehead model",
        "Improved approximate degree bounds for kğ‘˜k-distinctness",
        "Perceptrons: An Introduction to Computational Geometry",
        "On the degree of Boolean functions as real polynomials",
        "On the distributional complexity of disjointness",
        "Quantum communication complexity of symmetric predicates",
        "The sign-rank of ğ– ğ–¢0superscriptğ– ğ–¢0\\mathsf{AC}^{0}",
        "Explicit bounds for some functions of prime numbers",
        "Communication lower bounds using dual polynomials",
        "Separating ğ– ğ–¢0superscriptğ– ğ–¢0\\mathsf{AC}^{0} from depth-222 majority circuits",

        "The multiparty communication complexity of set disjointness",

}
